svdsort_test.cpp

Sorts the singular values in vector "wvecA" by descending order. For a singular value decomposition defined as

the resulting orthogonal matrices U and V and the singular values in W can be sorted in a way, that the singular values are given in descending order, when leaving the function.

Parameters:
umatA The matrix U.
vmatA The matrix V.
wvecA n-dimensional vector containing the singular values.
Returns:
none.
Exceptions:
check_exception the type of the exception will be "size mismatch" and indicates that wvecA is not one-dimensional
Please follow the link to view the source code of the example. The example can be executed in the example directory of package LinAlg.

Author:
M. Kreutz
Date:
1995
Changes
none
Status
stable
See also:
svd.cpp
00001 //===========================================================================
00051 //===========================================================================
00052 
00053 #include <iostream>
00054 #include "Array/ArrayIo.h"
00055 #include "LinAlg/linalg.h"
00056 
00057 using namespace std;
00058 
00059 int main() 
00060 {
00061     Array2D< double > A(2,2);    // input matrix 
00062     Array2D< double > U(2,2);    // the two orthogonal
00063     Array2D< double > V(2,2);    // matrices
00064     Array  < double > w(2);      // vector for singular values
00065     unsigned          curr_row,  // currently considered matrix
00066                       curr_col;  // row/column
00067 
00068     // Initialization values for input matrix:
00069     double input_matrix[4] = 
00070     { 
00071          1.,  3.,  
00072 
00073         -4.,  3.
00074     };
00075 
00076     // Initializing matrices and vector:
00077     for (curr_row = 0; curr_row < 2; curr_row++)
00078     {
00079         for (curr_col = 0; curr_col < 2; curr_col++)
00080         {
00081                 A(curr_row, curr_col) = input_matrix[curr_row*2+curr_col];
00082                 U(curr_row, curr_col) = 0.;
00083                 V(curr_row, curr_col) = 0.;
00084         }
00085           w(curr_row) = 0.;
00086     }
00087 
00088     // Singular value decomposition:
00089     svd(A, U, V, w);
00090 
00091 
00092     // Output before sorting:
00093     cout << "matrices and singular values before sorting:\n" << endl;
00094     cout << "input matrix:" << endl;
00095     writeArray(A, cout);
00096     cout << "column-orthogonal matrix U:" << endl;
00097     writeArray(U, cout);
00098     cout << "orthogonal matrix V:" << endl;
00099     writeArray(V, cout);
00100     cout << "vector of singular values:" << endl;
00101     writeArray(w, cout);
00102 
00103     // Sorting singular values, adjusting matrices:
00104     svdsort(U, V, w);
00105 
00106     // Output after sorting:
00107     cout << "\n\nmatrices and singular values after sorting:\n" << endl;
00108     cout << "column-orthogonal matrix U:" << endl;
00109     writeArray(U, cout);
00110     cout << "orthogonal matrix V:" << endl;
00111     writeArray(V, cout);
00112     cout << "vector of singular values:" << endl;
00113     writeArray(w, cout);
00114 
00115     return 0;
00116 }
